ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Thinking anthropologically about fieldwork. Formulating arguments about culture in Southeast Asia. Interrogating your assumptions about politics.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: strength: discussions were really interactive, books were engaging and interesting!
Its well organised and structured around books. I enjoyed the depth of discussion and the way prof Harms asked us to periodically complete work.

This is a combined grad-undergrad class, so expect some growing pains as these two kinds of groups sometimes struggle to really get along in terms having an academic discussion with good flow. The readings are all amazing, and Prof. Harms is a good seminar leader.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Succeeded: joint google docs for warm-ups, answering through zoom chats,

Prof Harms did a great job being compassionate and adapting to the circumstances including the unexpected tragedies that occurred this semester. He adapted the deadlines and gave us leeway to skip one weeks reading.
This course would have been much better with in-person instruction, as I assume most courses would be.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely recommend this course. There are not enough course offerings on Southeast Asia. This one is an excellent, intellectually rigorous primer.

If you are interested in Southeast Asian politics and culture, then definitely yes. If you come in knowing a little bit already about something specific about Southeast Asia (i.e. more than what you get out of CNN), even better. If you come in with the sole purpose on how to further rationalize your Southeast Asian fetish instead of going to therapy, Marvin Chun announced an expansion of mental health resources on campus recently.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

extras.title:
ANTH 588 01/ANTH 388 01
        Politics of Culture in SE Asia
